awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the participation of graduate students and early-career researchers in the fourth Midwest Machine Learning Symposium (MMLS), to be held in Chicago, Illinois, from May 16-17, 2023. The main objective of MMLS is to convene regional machine learning researchers for stimulating discussions and debates, to foster cross-institutional collaboration, and to showcase the collective talent of machine learning researchers at all career stages. The symposium will continue to enhance the visibility of machine learning research at Midwestern institutions. Furthermore, the focus on junior researchers, both at the student and junior faculty level, aid in the educational and professional development of this demographic group.

The format of the conference includes multiple plenary talks, invited sessions, contributed posters (with student poster awards), and panel discussions. The organizers strive to maintain a good balance of demographic and geographic diversity among invited speakers and co-organizers, and will also widely advertise the symposium to encourage diversity among participants. The website with details about the symposium is http://midwest-ml.org/2023/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Midwest Machine Learning Symposium, supported in part by the National Science Foundation, was a resounding success, achieving its goal of advancing machine learning in the Midwest region.

The symposium saw an unprecedented turnout, with over 490 registered participants and more than 350 daily attendees. This record-breaking participation was made possible by this award and the generous support of our sponsors, which allowed us to offer free registration. This enabled wide participation from students and researchers across the Midwest, fostering a collaborative and inclusive environment.

Participants from 20 universities in the region presented more than 140 posters, showcasing a diverse array of research. The symposium also featured four distinguished speakers, whose valuable insights were greatly appreciated by attendees, highlighting the high caliber of the event. Furthermore, this award specifically allowed us to provide travel support for six junior faculty members, which was crucial in promoting diversity and inclusion within the academic community. This support facilitated the sharing of a wide variety of perspectives, enriching the symposium’s discussions. Additionally, we were able to offer free accommodation to 65 students, significantly easing their financial burden and enhancing their symposium experience. Travel support was also extended to 30 women and members of historically underserved communities, further promoting inclusivity and diversity.

The Midwest Machine Learning Symposium has undoubtedly made a significant impact on the machine learning community in the region.

 

 

 


Last Modified: 06/24/2024
Modified by: Mladen Kolar
